newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn closes lower on technicals, wheat/soy.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn closes lower on technicals, wheat/soy.

text.p: Technical sell signals plus a sharp drop in wheat and soybeans knocked CBOT corn futures to a lower close, traders said.
The sag occurred despite a bullish USDA weekly export sales report and prospects for a slowdown in the U.S. corn harvest due to rainy weather, they said.
USDA Friday said U.S. corn net sales during the week ended October 10 tallied 858,000 tonnes, eight percent up from the previous week and 16 percent above the four-week average.
But chartists pointed to bearish flags for corn from the four- and 20-day moving averages.
Going into Friday's session the first resistance level for December was at $2.84-1/2 per bushel and second resistance was at $2.87-1/2. The session high for December was at $2.85-1/4.
First support for December was at $2.81-1/2, second support was at $2.78-1/2 and December closed at $2.80-1/4, indicating a potential bottom of the market may have been set.
The nine day relative strength index for December closed at 21.293 points. Traders generally view an RSI of 20 or less as indicative of a very oversold market.
Corn closed 1-1/2 to 3-1/4 cents per bushel lower, with December down three at $2.80-1/4.

The four and 20-day moving averages as of Thursday's close were giving off bearish signals before Friday's open and the fund selling was broad-based in early dealings but had slowed by the close, traders said.
E.D. and F. Man International sold six million bushels of December, Dean Witter Reynolds, R.J. O'Brien and Farmers Commodities Corp each sold two million bushels of December, floor sources said.
Corn futures volume was estimated at 53,000, up from 51,317 Thursday, according to the CBOT.
Corn options traders took note of Prudential Securities purchase of 550 December $3.20 calls at 1/4 cent and purchase of 500 December $3.10 calls at 1/2 to 5/8 cent, traders said.
Corn options volume was estimated at 26,000, up from 24,438 Thursday.
